Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Underground Infrastructure Sensing, Mapping and Modeling for Smart Maintenance, Sustainability and Usage

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project researches novel 3-D mapping techniques for the pipes and conduits carrying water, sewer, electricity, gas, telecommunications and steam underneath cities. Much of this infrastructure is aging and in unknown condition with unknown locations. The research uses a smart cities approach to managing information regarding urban underground utility infrastructure, as part of the US Ignite/NIST Global Cities Team Challenge (GCTC), operating in the adjacent cities of Burlington and Winooski. This is a small metropolitan region that enables ease of implementation of research efforts, yet big enough to elucidate key issues affecting scaling up to larger cities. The overall approach examines sensing and information technology to determine the state of infrastructure and provide it in an appropriate, timely and secure format for the managers, planners and users. The sensors include advanced ground penetrating radar and leak sensors connected to a high-speed network. Information will flow to and from a novel 3-D utility mapping and condition database. This information will be of use for presentation in graphical format for mobile and fixed devices, and for use by urban planners and engineers, along with maintenance and construction personnel.


This research addresses mapping and information processing of the location and condition of underground urban infrastructure. The primary research objectives are: 1. Urban underground 3-D utility mapping and sensor network database - This will be a novel system that integrates Building Information Modeling (BIM) and Geographical Information (GIS) database techniques; 2. Innovative high-speed tomographic ground penetrating radar (GPR) system - Imaging and assessing buried features is hampered by the congested nature of urban underground infrastructure. The research will examine advanced multi-static and phased array GPR techniques to measure scattering from pipes off-axis and to steer radar waves; 3. Underground water pipe monitoring sensor system - The design of the sensor network requires determining how to configure a heterogeneous mix of acoustic, pressure and flow metering sensors onto a high-speed fiber optic telemetry network, to detect, locate and assess leaks in fresh water supply systems. Prototyping experiments will start with acoustic sensors; 4. Digital and automated analysis tools - The GPR and sensor network data streams are multichannel, complicated and voluminous. Automated data processing methods are required for mapping and condition assessment, and 5. Field test research - Measure the performance of the utility mapping and sensor network database, associated instrumentation and analysis in the adjacent cities of Burlington and Winooski, VT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit outcomes of this research are techniques for improving the mapping and monitoring of urban subsurface infrastructure. The motivation is that underground utilities are critical infrastructure for all modern cities.  They carry drinking water, storm water, sewage, natural gas, electric power, telecommunications, steam, etc. This subsurface infrastructure reflects the growth and history of the city with many components aging, in unknown locations with congested configurations, and in unknown condition.

1. Urban underground 3-D utility mapping and sensor network database -Created a 3-D map of subsurface infrastructure from combination of data from geophysical sensors and 2-D maps.  The 3-D map is compatible with augmented reality display systems.

2. Innovative high-speed tomographic ground penetrating radar (GPR) system - The design of the system is to quickly scan and produce tomographic 3-D images of underground infrastructure.  The research developed and evaluated a variety of novel GPR techniques including multi-channel methods, the introduction of vorticity with Orbital Angular Momentum into radar beams, and the fusion with acoustic location techniques.

3. Underground water pipe monitoring sensor system - Developed sensor and magnetic telemetry system for underground sewer pipes that can send wireless signals through soil that blocks conventional WiFi and radio waves. Above ground the sensor system uses a LoRa network to connect to the internet.

4. Digital and automated analysis tools - Data from geophysical sensors, such as ground penetrating radar and acoustic pipe locators, are combined with as-built drawings to create 3-D maps of underground infrastructure that can be viewed in an augmented reality format on handheld devices or specialized goggles, both onsite and offsite.

5. Field test research - Measure the performance of the utility mapping and sensor network database, associated instrumentation and analysis. Tests of the techniques occurred at various locations on the University of Vermont campus; Winooski, VT, including Orchard Terrace with newly rebuilt subsurface infrastructure; South Burlington, VT, including the magnetic wireless telemetry of signals through the ground from a storm sewers; Moon Brook Pond Dam in Rutland, VT for historic subsurface construction; and multiple locations around Vermont with local natural gas utility examining subsurface features corresponding to potentially dangerous cross-bore geometries due to trenchless gas line installation, and the condition of trenches that result from cut and cover construction of gas lines through rocky soils.  These tests were largely successful.

The broader impacts outcomes of this research are: 1. The training and professional development of multiple individuals in various stages of education through research, teaching and mentoring activities directly and indirectly related to this project.   2. Actively participated in the NIST Global Cities Team Challenge and Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) Model for Underground Data Definition and Integration MUDDI meetings. 3. Received Smart 50 Award for Underground Infrastructure Monitoring as part of Smart Cities Connect and US Ignite Conference in Kansas City, MO, 2018. 4. Disseminated results at multiple technical conferences, including a live and demonstration of augmented reality underground utility pipe rendering March 29, 2017 at the Smart Cities Conference, Kansas City, MO.  The demonstration included a live presentation on stage, and remote live interactive links with students and collaborators in Burlington, VT and Chattanooga, TN.  5. Met with and presented details on the research with multiple municipal utility managers and engineers.
